There was a time i never really took pride in where I live (the point). I remember this one day me and my friends were all sitting at the lunch table and we were talking about where we lived, I said the obviously "the point." Then my friends started talking about how only no good people live there and you walk down the street you'd get shot. I was like .. I haven't been shot & I'm a very good student. I don't drink or smoke. Ever since that day I just wanted to prove them wrong. I graduated with awards that year. I just recently was a Runner-up for the MLK essay, I'm in National Honor society, I have A's & B's, & etc. I never been so proud of where I live & still am. Who said nothing good ever comes out of the point ?
replies: I don't know who says that,but you're right,good things can happen in the point.\\ Your pride is inspiring, and I hope it inspires others to represent their community, too!

[[[42.521931, -70.891884]]]\nLet's say I was giving this Tour in October ..First stop would be... the Peabody Essex Museum. Many may say something like, "Why it's boring." It honestly not. I've been there about a million time, and the only thing that keeps me interested is that there's always something new. It blends cultures all into one facility. This one building is where the diversity starts.Next stop would be... the carnival. Every year around the month of October they put of a carnival. I think these are one of the events that makes the community and strangers to the area come together and enjoy themselves. "The point" not only supports education but shows we also have the ability to have fun... together.

I don't live or work in the Point, although I have lived in neighborhoods in two other cities where there was a concentration of poverty. In those two places, there was also a higher crime rate (far higher than in the Point) than in more prosperous neighborhoods. When I lived in those two neighborhoods, the two things I liked least were worrying about my safety and how the neighborhoods were portrayed.Despite real safety issues (a man down the hall in my apartment building was shot out front of the building, my car was hit and run, and rowdy drunks would yell at night), I had wonderful neighbors, a beautiful and active park, and locally owned shops where the business people knew me. Many of us were working to make the neighborhood safer. And although there were real issues, the way the media portrayed the neighborhoods gave a far worse impression of the area than the reality.The Point doesn't have the level of crime that these two neighborhoods had. Yet, the broader perception of the neighborhood, and often how it is portrayed, makes it seem much worse. It drove me crazy that we couldn't get positive stories out about the neighborhoods I lived in, and I imagine I would fee the same way if I lived or worked in the Point.
Good\nI know the Mayor and many in the city government care a lot about the Point. However, there are a lot of needs and the city can't do everything on its own.

I don't live or work in the Point. What I imagine to be advantages are the walkability and proximity to downtown. I've heard that there is a tight community as well, although my sense is it's tight for the immigrant community and there isn't much engagement with the non-immigrant community.

Hopefully this game, and the broader planning process, will result in the vision that partners can then implement.

I used to live in a neighborhood with a "problem house." It was owned by an absentee landlord and the tenants caused all sorts of problems. They were physically abusive to their pets, yelled insults at neighbors, played incredibly loud music in the middle of the night, and probably were up to a variety of illegal activities that I don't know about. Together with my neighbors, we documented the problems to the police, tracked down the landlord, and got the tenants evicted. We even found a new owner that fixed up the house. The result was transformational--not just for the property but for the sense of belonging the neighbors developed for each other.
The apartment buildings along Peabody Street are wonderful.

The Point is unique in Salem--from the architecture to the people to the history to the shops. A visitor would get to experience an authentic neighborhood with its own identity. UNACCOMPANIED HOMELESS YOUTH Unaccompanied youth homelessness is a public health crisis not only throughout the world but throughout our community. Young adults who struggle with homelessness don't only struggle with inadequate housing but may also be coping with mental, emotional, or physical health problems, substance abuse, violence, and family struggles. Every human shares the same basic necessities such as food, water, shelter, warmth, and hygiene. According to Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs, without these basic needs, an individual cannot focus on further achievements such as employment, stability, health, resources, relationships, self-esteem, and inner talents. Many people who experience homelessness include young adults who are given limited options to seek their full potential.      In fact, the concern for unaccompanied youth homelessness in Massachusetts is being acknowledged more today than it ever has. There is a bill known as the Act Providing Housing Support Services for Unaccompanied Homeless Youth that will be addressed at the State House on February 27. This bill is being addressed in hopes to reduce youth homelessness with a series of improvements such as increased housing and support services that will be aimed specifically for unaccompanied youth as well as bettering stability, education, physical and mental health.This bill also suggests rather than serving young adults 22 and younger, to extend to the age of 24 and younger.    This population of young adults is difficult to count because they don•À_t always identify themselves as homeless. Not only that but they are tracked by reports from schools, shelters, and other social service agencies. If the young adult isn•À_t in-rolled in any of these services then they will go unnoticed. According to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education, there is an estimated 6,000 high school students that are homeless on their own. According to state educational officials, there is an estimated 13,090 homeless students in which 735 of them are defined as unaccompanied.       In Salem, Massachusetts there is a Day program called Journeys of Hope that serves homeless young adults from the ages of 18-23. There is currently 82 young adults in Salem that seek help through Journeys of hope today. In addition, 29% of the 47 students who attend Salem Community Charter School in Downtown Salem are housing unstable or homeless. The only shelter in the area that provides a bed to sleep in at night is a shelter called Lifebridge. Even so, this shelter is for people of all ages that are struggling with homelessness and many other issues.   Young adults need their own space to build themselves from the ground up.  With the obstacles they are already facing, they need somewhere temporarily stable to feel comfortable and safe to sleep at. They meet numerous strangers day by day but what they will really benefit form is a place surrounded by other young adults facing the same challenges. Not just that, but they need to be assured that they are safe and their belongings will be free from harm. If that is not provided then young adults are more likely to avoid shelters and put themselves in more risk. Without a secure youth based environment, most homeless young adults across the world will continue to lack personal growth.By: Mariah DoranCome support us at the State house on Wednesday, February 27, 2013 at 9:00am. You can come as a supporter, say a testimony, or create an art piece on your perception or experience with homelessness that will be hanged up at the State House for a week.

response: [[[42.521644027981694, -70.8912725982666]]]\nIf I were giving a tour on Salem I would start at the Old Burying Point which is the second oldest cemetery in the country. Justice John Hathorne was buried here who was one of the leading judges during the which trials and also the ancestor of Nathaniel Hawthorne who was a well known novelist from Salem. I would also show the tour the Samuel Pickman House which is one of the oldest buildings still standing in Salem and the Witch Trials Memorial which is dedicated to all of those who were executed in 1692. Those who were executed could not have a proper burial since they weren't considered Christian. I would also include how Salem was called Naumkeag by the Naumkeag Tribe that meant "fishing place," until it was changed three years after the first settler, Roger Conant arrived. It was then changed to Salem, short for Jerusalem, meaning "city of peace." On my tour I would talk about all of the history of Salem and show people many historical sites to remember.

Making sure that all communications (posters, emails) are in both English and Spanish (and in other languages spoken by residents) would be really important. When people arrive, it would be great to have greeters of all ages (serving on or recruited by the Organizing Committee) ready to personally  welcome each person that shows up and tell them about the range of activities happening and planned. Also as other people have said, having things like a bouncy castle, music, food, and stations with different activities will create many options for people of all ages.

I think the block party should go from noon to 5 pm and be full of family friendly things for people of all ages to do. It would be open to people who live, work, and go to school in the neighborhood. There can be a poster somewhere indicating the range of activities. It would be great for there to be food stations with cuisine from restaurants in the Point neighborhood. An Organizing Committee in partnership with the City could raise funds to cover food so this does not need to be sought out as donations. It would be great to identify people who have artistic skills and live or work in the neighborhood who could play music during the event. It would also be great to have a craft station where people can contribute to a collective project (collage, mural, etc.) Perhaps there could be a place where people can get their very own photo with the Mayor! Since there is a basketball court, there could a tournament as well (perhaps one for youth and another for adults?) There should also be some way for people to contribute funds towards next year's block party.There shouldn't be much of a formal speaking program, though. But, the Organizing Committee should definitely say a few works on a loudspeaker at a few key points to welcome people.It would be great to give room for longtime residents to share a bit about how the neighborhood has changed over the years so newer residents have some background on how the neighborhood has and is continuing to change. It would also be fantastic if the Mayor could attend and meet some residents.

[[[42.51364123786287, -70.89036064720153]]]\nPalmer Cove Park has beautiful views of the waterfront and there is a fair amount of lawn space. There is also the basketball court so should folks want to get some exercise after eating, they can shoot some hoops.

OK\nWhen I participated in walking tours of the neighborhood, I noticed a lot of trash in many of the parks. Also, a better variety of seating in the parks and more plantings could also make them more visually appealing for folks who may just want to sit and relax. These types of improvements can make the parks enjoyable for a variety of ages. There is also the need for a park that includes a safety gate and play structures appropriate for toddlers. Also, fountains are always popular. If one of the parks had a spray fountain it could be a lot of fun in the summer.

There are a couple of options. If it isn't too cold out, she can take them to one of the parks, like Mary Jane Lee Park. She could walk with them to the Harbor Walk entrance, which is at the edge of the neighborhood. She can then take them for froyo at Orange Leaf Yogurt. Unfortunately there aren't any good indoor recreational options right in the neighborhood. However, there are people who live and work in the community who are interested in securing resources to creating a real community center for the neighborhood that will have year-round activities for people who live in the Point.

[[[42.517136653681185, -70.88943796730041]]]\nThere is a large parking lot on Congress street on the block between Harbor and Dow streets. If we could transform this parking lot or the parking spaces adjacent to it, I envision two possibilities:1) a temporary recycling station with bins. We could invite passerby and people who live in apartment buildings that do not offer recycling to bring their items by. It could give a sense of the amount of material that could be recycled in a day in the Point.2) a healthy food access info station. We could hand out "seed bombs" of veggies that people can plant and grow when they get home. It can be used to build knowledge of the community gardens in the Point and be an opportunity for the Salem Mass-in-Motion program to survey residents about their interests in a local farmers market and what types of goods it should carry.
Good food options, Open late / open early, Outdoors

In my neighborhood (the Dorchester neighborhood of Boston) I am in close proximity to a variety of things to do. Most important to me is the diversity of places from which I can get food. A few blocks down the street is a hub of Vietnamese restaurants. There is a grocery store about 10 minutes away by bike. There are a number of small grocery/corner stores that carry specialty foods used in Vietnamese cuisine as well as more traditional offerings. There are many bars and pubs. Outside of my neighborhood but within driving distance there is a bowling alley, though it is not very accessible by walking or public transportation.There is one independent, woman-owned shop I like very much that is just a few blocks away.There are also several dollar stores in my neighborhood. The kinds of shops I like to frequent in other neighborhoods feature goods made locally, whether it is accessories, clothing, food, art, etc. I wish there were more stores highlighting locally made goods in my neighborhood. I know there are artists living and working in Dorchester, and it would be so great to have a place to see and buy what they make.

There are a couple of organizations in the Point that offer after-school activities that may be of interest to Freddy. The On Point Teen Resource Center is run through a collaboration between the Salem Police Department, Essex County Juvenile Court, and the Plummer Home. It offers a music program, sports (e.g., basketball tournaments), and other activities open to all youth -- boys and girls -- in the neighborhood. If he has any interest in computers, Salem CyberSpace also offers a space to learn computer programs as well as college prep and summer programs.
Two-three times a week\nI love going outside when the weather is nice. I rode my bike, went for walks along the waterfront, and rode some trails.

I live in Boston but every now and then my partner and I will take trips to other parts of the state -- usually for food! We love trying different types of cuisine. I could definitely see myself coming to the Point to eat at one of the restaurants. If the weather was nice, I might take the Commuter Rail up from Boston and walk the short 10 minutes it takes to get to the Point.

I would share two resources with Timothy. The Salem Chamber of Commerce meets regularly and I would encourage him to become a member and to get support from other business owners in the greater Salem area. response: There are banks, restaurants, beauty salons and convenience stores/bodegas where you can buy some staples (not all) in the Point.  Nonprofits like Salem CyberSpace and the North Shore CDC's youth jobs program also provides good skills training. What's missing: To buy more basic groceries, you need to travel out of the neighborhood.There is also no community center in the neighborhood that provides a variety of activities for residents of all ages.

I do not live in the Point but if I were to imagine what it would be like to live here, I would say that there are places to go to eat and have drinks with friends, but there isn't any place where I can really do grocery shopping for basic staples. I would say that there are a good number of parks to bring friends with kids or teens, but no real place to enjoy open space (although the Waterfront is very nearby, I can't easily get to it or even see it from where I live).If I were to imagine what it would be like to work here, I would say that I don't know very much about the job opportunities in Shetland Park and I wonder if there are jobs suitable to different educational backgrounds and skill levels. I'd be interested in learning more about opportunities to work there.

OK\nThe city has made many investments in the neighborhood in areas like tree plantings, targeting grant funds to improve the quality of public housing, and allocating funds for first time homebuyer programs. But there are areas for improvement. This project is timely because it gives the chance for the city to better understand the infrastructure and social service needs of the neighborhood using feedback directly provided by people who live, work, study, and play in the neighborhood.

I don't live in the Point but it reminds me of the neighborhood I grew up in, which had many immigrant-owned businesses including restaurants, beauty salons, and specialty stores. Very Poor\nI hear people complain all the time about the 'extra' services the Point receives from the city and I can sympathize with them in a way.  The fact, however, is the neighborhood is home to so many more people than the rest of Salem that extra services are not just a freebee but a necessity.  I still feel much more should be done regarding litter and upkeep in and around absentee owned properties.  A campaign to encourage individual responsibility to not litter would be nice as well.

[[[42.51806978592641, -70.89315014457702]]]\nThe section of Lafayette St at the Lafayette Hotel and Wendy's is my choice.  This area, will be the turning point for the entire Point neighborhood.  If businesses move in, and continue to do well, they will act as a type of glue to connect the Point seamlessly with the rest of downtown Salem.  Removing clear barriers of 'us vs. them' attitude is an important step in getting the Point back to being a place for both tourists and locals to enjoy- night and day.
replies: Great answer,\\ Agreed!\\ Totally agree, it helps our city

response: Berube and Sons Funeral Home celebrates its 73rd year as a family-owned business located in Salem's Point neighborhood!  Our business was started on Harrison Ave back in 1940 when most funerals and wakes were being held in people's own homes.  Back then funeral directors needed just enough space to display a few caskets and have an office and a room to prepare the deceased.  As time went on and things changed, we eventually moved to our location on Lafayette St.  We are now in our third generation and are happy to be a part of the history and are proud members of Salem's Point Neighborhood.
For most things I need I go to Crosby's on Canal St.  There are a lot of times I will go for smaller items on Congress St. Market.

I see that a lot of young people have to either walk or wait for rides in order to get around. If they stay at school for our College Success Program, then getting home to the Point afterwards is a challenge. I would like for young people (and adults) to see bicycling as a mode of transportation. It's reliable and cheap! No driver's license needed. I would therefore like to start a program to repair donated bikes, provide young people in the Point with these bikes, and educate them on proper maintenance and operation. This way they get some exercise, learn basic skills, and become more independent and responsible.
replies: This is a great idea, Monique. There are two bike shops in downtown (Salem Cycle and the Urbane Cyclist) who may want to get involved with program like this. There was also a free bike share program up by the Hawthorne Hotel a couple of years ago, is that still around? If so, it could be a valuable asset to this idea, too. \\ Thanks Laurie! Do you know who was running/involved with the free bike share program?\\ Looks like the program, Salem Spins, is run through the city and paid for by a grant. Here's an article about it from the Salem News: http://www.salemnews.com/local/x2108293973/A-SECOND-CYCLE

replies: Sometimes the simplest thoughts are the most profound. Luis' suggestion reminded me that The Point has included a succession of immigrant populations for more than a century. Besides reaching across current generations, how about reaching back generations to remember and celebrate the people who have previously populated The Point -- French-Canadians, Polish, etc. This also reminds me that The Point is not entirely Latino now. Maybe predominantly, but not entirely. There are still remnants of previous generations and heritages represented in the neighborhood.

The point is a very safe place to be. As a young girl growing up in the point, it's the only place I felt safe, actually. Everywhere else was really quite and spooky; like if someone you didn't know was going to pop out of nowhere. In the point, just about everyone is a familiar face. There are cultural murals, bodegas to eat cultural food (where you can't really find any other place in Salem). Just the other day a women came up to my family when and we were grilling some meat in the streets. We invited her in to eat and try our Dominican food (she said no, but that okay!). We're very open people, and love to meet others.

response: I do not often feel unsafe although working in the neighborhood for years, there have been a few moments of uncertainty.  In one instance, there was a large youth fight complete with shovels, bars, etc. and as I squared off against a young man I remember thinking "the worst that could happen is I'd lose my teeth if he hit me with that shovel, right?"  All managed to work out fine and he dropped the shovel and left.  That was a rare occasion!  Really, I feel very safe although uneasy when signs seems to indicate that there might be illegal activities going on in the streets.

I would change the amount of trash in the streets.  That is the issue that is most visible on a walk or drive through.  To dig into meatier issues, one has to do more than just walk through!  The question of how to change the trash is a good one.  I would have more frequent trash removal, better public trash cans, and campaigns with residents to clean up more frequently.  The wind tunnel effect in this neighborhood blows trash around and so, often, others' trash can come knocking at one's door.

Timothy and his brother have a bit of a challenge luring folks onto Congress St. out of downtown, but they can be creative, using marketing opportunities online (e.g., groupons) and recruiting folks at some of the many outside events in Salem (e.g. Haunted Happenings).  They should join the Chamber if they have not already done so.  Once they win customers, it shouldn't be hard to keep them!

[[[42.51837028317455, -70.89305358505248]]]\nI must say that I still lament the passing of Red Raven's Love Noodle.  That place was unique - both in it's decor and food.  It really brought folks into the neighborhood like no other place since has.  Although I have not been in a while, Brisas del Caribe was a favorite for Dominican food.

Day care, school, and, for some, work is readily available.  Basic groceries, pharmacy, convenience, and some clothing, medical, beauty needs are available in the Point.  If residents desire large grocery stores, clothing stores, most medical attention, etc., they need to venture out of the neighborhood.

The Point is right on the water, but there is limited access and views of it.  There continue to be issues with trash removal and public trash cans in the streets.  Working in the Point at Shetland Park, parking is easy, but some folks fear the neighborhood and that may detract from demand for businesses.

OK\nThis neighborhood is a focus of attention for the city government, but we haven't found the right formula for meeting the people's needs.  Some of the investments in  infrastructure have been positive (e.g., river walk, Palmer cove), but more could be done from trash collection to crosswalks, attracting representation from the people, etc.

I work in the Point and love the richness of the location.  It is easily accessible to downtown, is right on the water, and is bustling with energy.  Many of our students (Salem Academy) walk to school from within the point or the surrounding neighborhoods.

I would write about this game and what fun it's been to hear perspectives about the neighborhood from residents, those that work in the point and others who don't know much about the area.  Poignant for me has been listening to the reflections and opinions of the students at our school.  Thanks to everyone for sharing.

The streets are very narrow in the Point, and there are often groups of kis or teens hanging out outside. I'm often nervous driving in the Point for fear that I'll accidentally hit someone (or come close). I also feel vaguely unwelcome in the Point, but that's probably just white guilt.

The streets are in bad shape in the Point; there are lots of potholes and cracks, and a lot of the signs need replacing. A lot of the houses also look very run-down and dingy. The Point makes me feel claustrophobic. The buildings are all too close together, the streets are too narrow, and it's all a little looming and dirty and threatening. If I lived or worked in the Point, I'd appreciate more clean, open spaces with new pavement and better signage to make the place feel better taken care of.

Poor\nOver the last 10 years or so Salem has enjoyed something of a Renaissance, with lots of new restaurants and businesses opening and lots of paving and other improvement projects. However, I've seen no evidence that any of those improvements have been in the Point. They're focusing on the more touristy areas, which makes sense, but the Point could really use a makeover.

I do not live or work in the Point, but if I did I'd be very happy with its centralized location in Salem. Just about everywhere in the Point is within walking distance of good restaurants, grocery and convenient stores, the downtown shopping area and museums, and the ocean. Parking can be nasty all over Salem year round, but especially during tourist season, so being within walking distance of all the best places to eat and hang out in Salem is a huge plus.

I don't live in the Point, and the reasons that I do not are, I'm sure, the same that those that live there will list as "the worst of the Point." Namely:1) Safety. Whether or not it's true, there is a perception that the Point is not safe. As we saw in the last mission, the Point has the most crimes reported each year, and the second most per capita of all the neighborhoods in Salem. There was a stabbing in the neighborhood in 2012(?), a person loose in the area wielding a machete, and a not inconsiderable gang and drug presence.2) Cleanliness. Enough said.3) Housing. The Point has a reputation as a run-down neighborhood. Yes, it's historic with many beautiful buildings constructed around 1914, but that also means they are old, and old buildings deteriorate if not carefully kept up. Additionally, most houses in the Point are apartment units, or condo units being rented out, and I prefer a single family detached living space.

I think an investment in infrastructure would be most helpful to businesses.  For residents seeking job training or jobs, there is the N. S. Career Center.  However, a location in the Point for job training and placement services would also be useful.

Energy efficiency improvements, More affordable home ownership,  Mitigating lead-based paint hazard, Assistance to rehabilitate homes,  Historic preservation\nAssistance with rent doesn't really relate to housing quality, unless it means the landlords will invest more of the rents into the buildings.  Pride of homeownership can help improve housing quality.  Making rentals more affordable is not going to help housing quality.   The City has programs for lead paint abatement, rehabilitation, etc.

Congress Street is very unattractive, although it has improved with the redesign of Congress/Peabody/Ward.  A redesign to a more plaza feel (even making the street narrower), with pedestrian lighting and street furniture could help jump start the improvement of storefronts and create a domino effect.

A new location would not likely change the situation.  It is the economy in general.  Like all businesses, whether in the Point or outside, they will need to target their marketing to the types of customers they are trying to reach.  Are they trying to reach more residential or commercial?  Are they trying to reach the owners and landlords in the neighborhood?  Are they trying to market to Salem?  to nearby communities?

[[[42.5185624, -70.8932403]]]\nAfter starting a the Harborwalk and then touring the residential areas, I would end up at lower Lafayette to show the investment made or being made in the Point, including Heritage Bank, Glitterati, Salem Cyberspace and NSCDC to name a few.  And, love it or hate it, I would also show the investment being made at the former St. Joseph's complex.   Then we would all go into Red Lulu for a cocktail!

Teen Resource Center Keeps Kids "On Point"On Point, a collaborative of the Salem Police Department, Essex County Juvenile court and the Plummer Home, is held at the Teen Resource Center on Leavitt Street.  It focuses on at risk youth and those involved with the Juvenile Justice system.  The SPD's Community Impact Unit operates this community service program to provide a positive environment to help prevent youth from involvement in drugs, alcohol, gangs or crime.  Initially, many kids are court-involved in the program, doing community service projects in the Point Neighborhood.  However, many stay on after satisfying their obligations.  Along with projects (i.e. grafitti removal, park projects, painting), there are basketball and flag football games versus the police, pizza parties and other special events,  It is estimated that 100 community youth visit the program on a weekly bases.  They take advantage of games and snacks provided by the Plummer Home, who also has a coordinator to oversee the program.  The building that houses the Teen Resource Center is currently being expanded by the City to accommodate the space demands of this successful program.

Safe, Good food options, Affordability\nFirst and foremost I want to feel safe, but I'm also on a budget and like lots of food options. Parking nearby would be great too, but I am willing to walk if need be.
Mini golf and bowling are not nearby. I'd like to see a small concert venue, more sit-down restaurants, and an ice cream parlor.

There will be other sports and extra-curricular activities available for Freddy through his school, but depending on why he got kicked off the basketball team, he might not be eligible for those activities. There is also the On Point teen center and a short walk to the Boys' and Girls' Club.
Four or more times a week\nI like to spend time in my garden and grilling with friends.
On a Friday night, I would probably go meet friends for dinner or drinks at a restaurant downtown. Depending on the time of year, I might walk or I might drive my car.
[[[42.51402083999352, -70.88882642364501]]]\nPalmer cove is an open green space right on the water. The community garden was one of my favorite places to go when I lived in the Point.

Business expansion loans, Commercial business rehabilitation,  Job creation,  Job training and placement\nI think all of these ideas would work hand in hand. I had to look up what commercial business rehabilitation meant, perhaps that could be better explained in the question. As I understand it, it means financial assistance for businesses to help them improve or renovate the buildings that house their businesses. I think that a program like this could help Point businesses become more aesthetically appealing to customers and help drive business. Loans to help businesses in the Point expand could provide more job opportunities for residents, and could funding resources into other methods of job creation. Of course, businesses can only hire people who are qualified to fill their open positions, so job training and placement is important as well.

More affordable home ownership, Assistance to rehabilitate homes\nI think people take more pride in homes that they own themselves. It is easy not to care about the place where you live when the landlord is never around and doesn't seem to care about keeping the building maintained. I'd like to see more people own their own homes or condos, or for the landlords to live in the buildings that they rent out.

I would say the folks at LifeBridge could be a good resource for Timothy's neighbors. While LifeBridge provides services for those who are already homeless, I'm sure they could put Timothy's neighbors in touch with services for those who are in danger of losing their home.
[[[42.51617187518397, -70.89011388397216]]]\nThere always seems to be a lot of litter everywhere, but the worst places are near convenience stores, restaurants, and parks.

I've never felt unsafe driving through the Point, although those narrow one-way streets when there are snowbanks in the winter can be a little tough to navigate. I used to often walk through the Point from my workplace on Derby St down Congress street on my way to my apartment by way of Palmer Cove park. I never felt unsafe walking there in the daytime. Sometimes I would walk down Lafayette St. instead to travel to or from downtown, and I sometimes felt a little intimidated by a man in a wheelchair asking for money. He would sometimes follow me up the block or yell things.

Clean up the litter would be my first thought, traveling through the Point. A community group that meets once a week to walk through the neighborhood and clean it up might inspire others to stop littering. Also, installing some of those nice solar powered trash compactor bins that are in downtown would be helpful. My second thought would be to do something with the vacant lot fronted by concrete jersey barriers on Ward St. What an eyesore. Who owns that property? The neighborhood kids often play there, and it would be nice if it was a maintained green space instead of litter strewn blacktop.

For an electrician, location of his shop shouldn't matter that much, as he would typically be going out to job sites to perform his work. From his shop on Congress street he could be going out to jobs anywhere on the North Shore. Being bilingual is an asset he could advertise to get more work with Spanish speaking customers in his own neighborhood, however, many residents in the Point do not own their homes and would be dependent on their landlords to hire an electrician when needed.

[[[42.511245, -70.89170999999999]], [[42.511245, -70.89170999999999]]]\nChristina's pizza was my favorite when I lived in the Point, although it is on the outskirts of the neighborhood. The owners were very nice, service was quick, and the food was good.

There are lots of convenience stores and bodegas in the Point, so residents have no problem picking up a few necessities here and there. There are also several take out restaurants in the Point, so they can get a bite to eat. The Point lacks places to go shopping for clothes or home goods, a full service grocery store, and a pharmacy, although those things are within walking distance downtown and on Canal street.

When I lived in the Point, my biggest challenge was the proximity of inconsiderate neighbors. They did not think about how their loud music and late parties would negatively impact people nearby. I also once had a downstairs neighbor whose party guest set the coat closet on fire with a cigarette butt at 2am. The other issue I had finding parking near my apartment, as we did not have off-street parking. It was especially challenging during snow bans, as we would have to walk 6 blocks to the nearest snow ban parking. Not so bad for me as a single 20-something, but I can't imagine walking that far in snow and ice if I had small children, physical handicap, or was elderly.

OK\nI think city government is providing basic services that they provide for all areas of Salem, such as trash pickup and snow removal, but I don't know about anything special they do for Point residents.

I lived in the point for about 10 years starting in 2002, right out of college at Salem State. I was working at Salem State's summer theatre that summer, and choose the apartment for its proximity to North Campus and its affordability. I also liked being close enough to walk downtown to shop and visit the library. Five years into my time in the point, I got a job on Derby St, and I would walk there when the weather was nice. Two years before I moved away I got a plot in the community garden at Palmer Cove, and I have to say that was my favorite part of living in the Point.
replies: I did not know that there was a community garden at Palmer Cove. Good to know!

When I lived in the Point, I used to walk down to Crosby's on Canal Street. They have most things in the way of groceries, although they are more expensive than other local grocery stores. I lived near other convenience stores that I could visit in a pinch, too, but they didn't have a full selection of products. At that time Eaton Apothecary was also open in the Crosby's plaza, and I used to have my prescriptions filled there. The nearest pharmacy would now be Walgreens on New Derby Street, I believe, which is not nearly as convenient to the end of the Point that I lived on, although it is fairly close to other end of the neighborhood.

He needs to figure out why business is falling off, and in the meantime, he might approach his landlord about arranging a temporary rent reduction, in lieu of which he may have to vacate the space.Since electrical work is generally site-specific, it shouldn't matter that his operation is housed in the Point (not that this should be regarded a liability anyway, unless he perceives his prospective clientele as limited to Point denizens - not a good model for any tradesperson). I would encourage him to investigate how his business is being rated on Angie's List and on YELP!; if he does not have a profile or it is not positive, I would encourage him to ask all of his satisfied customers to log on and make their positive assessments known. Most business is built by word-of-mouth, and increasingly, that means via on-line channels. He may need to invest in building a website. Many free or low cost apps are available to help one build-your-own and affordable assistance may be available from a local designer.His bi-lingualism is a real asset; make sure any marketing materials emphasize this. In addition to on-line marketing and trying to reach beyond the neighborhood for clientele, it might be worth it to review who the current owners of properties in the point are and to introduce or reintroduce himself to them, maybe distribute a flyer about his services (and the fact that he's local) - perhaps play up a service to do a flat-rate thorough inspection and assessment of a building's electrical system and needs.

Please see answer to challenge #2. The amount of what appears to be unused wiring and power boxes hanging/dangling from poles and buildings throughout the Point is a real - unsightly and potentially dangerous - problem. I have tried in the past to contact utility companies and city offices about removal, all of which have pointed fingers at the others and refused any responsibility for or help to address the problem. Even though a great proportion of Point residents walk more than drive and walkability could be one of the neighborhood's best assets, I have experienced extreme frustration as a pedestrian. Crosswalks are often not well-kept up and drivers never cited for infractions against pedestrians' safety. As much as the PrimeEnergy gas station is a neighborhood asset, one sometimes takes one's life into one's hands when walking (and sometimes driving) past, due to its entrance/exit set-up. After snowfalls, long stretches of sidewalks (near abandoned lots or semi-public spaces) are left unplowed, which has made passage difficult for an able-bodied person, never mind someone impaired by injury or age. Garbage in the streets and lack of trees or other flora make the environment unsightly and unappealing to walk in.I enjoy when people gather outside on sidewalks/stoops, but the drug dealing and loitering between buildings and alleys is certainly unpleasant and can feel dangerous. Kids as well as adults need someplace to gather that is safe and comfortable when private spaces are overcrowded and often ill-kept by landlords. Enforcement of late-night noise ordinances could be improved.Traffic flow and speeds, as well as parking policies through the Point's narrow streets need attention. Perhaps traffic should flow only in one direction on Salem St. (perhaps N-S from Palmer to Chase and S-N from Palmer to Harbor) and Chase Street (E-W). Parking should be prevented on Salem Street between Palmer and Leavitt or at minimum, must be confined to one side.Find places for and plant some TREES.

Poor\nTrash and snow removal services, apparently unused and dangerous phone, cable and electrical wires, uneven sidewalks & lack of landscaping, are major problems. Although issues partly attributable to residents and the dense population of renters, there are few trash/recycling receptacles available in public spaces and the few existing, such as along the sea wall at Palmer's Cove, are infrequently attended to (why can't Waste Management waste/compost/recyclers as exist downtown be placed throughout the Point?); contractors Northside Crating fling garbage into trucks such that debris is scattered all over the street and then throw garbage cans INTO the street rather than upright back on the sidewalks. As for snow removal, rarely is plowing done curb-to-curb, despite the narrow streets and concentration of on-street parking. Sidewalks in front of buildings or lots not clearly owned by anyone are left unplowed to the detriment of the Point's many pedestrians, especially the elderly.

The best aspects of living in the Point, are its proximity to the ocean/bay, its walkability to both downtown and Salem State, Palmer's Cove Park and Community Garden, the ethnic, age, and income diversity, the architecture, and the locally-owned and operated small businesses that reflect and cater to that diversity.

Other things that are not in the neighborhood are clothing stores (very limited and nothing for men).  There also are not a lot of restaurants in the Point.  There is nowhere where you can have a large family meal (sit-down dinner) for Dominican food in the Point!  There are a couple of small places to get take-out, but nothing on the fancier side.  We need this!  It would be a huge draw for people from around the North Shore to come to the Point.

He has a few choices - he could go to the Salem Boys and Girls Club - they have a great Teen Director and a bunch of cool programs, and it only costs $10/year to be a member.  He could also apply for a scholarship to the Salem Y - a bit further, but still within a short walk from Peabody Street.  Or he could go to Salem Cyberspace, which is basically across the street.

Job creation,  Job training and placement\nJob training programs that are tailored to the skill set of many people in the Point would be great.  A mix of English-language and Spanish-language programs would be great.  And programs that reach both teens and young adults who either didn't finish high school or who completed high school and have been stuck since would be great.

More affordable rental housing, Energy efficiency improvements\nThe quality of housing in the Point is as big an issue as the cost of housing - too often places are affordable, but they are not healthy, safe, attractive homes.  It's tough for people who want to live in the Point or need an affordable place with few options to turn to.  Funding should be directed towards creating quality, affordable housing and to energy efficiency improvements.  Often, one of the worst issues in a poor-quality apartment is energy efficiency - drafty windows, old furnace, poorly-insulated walls, old light fixtures - all of those things, if updated, can be more energy efficient, lower utility bills and look better as well.

I would first tell him to tell them not to leave their apartment unless the landlord had received an execution.  So often, people think they have to leave their apartment when they get their first notice-to-quit, and that's just not the case.  Force the landlord to go through the full eviction process, if nothing else to keep a roof over his friend's head for a while longer.In the meantime, I would tell him to connect with agency such as NSCAP in Peabody or Catholic Charities in Salem for some help with housing search.  Checking out craigslist is always a good thing for current listings too.  And to get on the waiting list at North Shore CDC for affordable housing is a good idea.

[[[42.51564993962455, -70.8906074104309]]]\nPalmer Street tends to have a trash problem, probably because of a few things - the market, the park, etc.  We have got to try to add some trash barrels to see if that works - having none at all certainly does not.We should also talk about incentivizing local businesses to take care of them.  Maybe a discount on their property taxes if they maintain a public trash barrel or two?

I have spent countless hours in the Point neighborhood at all times of the day and evening, and not once have I felt unsafe or intimidated.  I understand that crime happens, but I continue to believe that it does not happen at any greater rate in the Point than anywhere else.  Trouble tends to find people who are looking for it, not random bystanders.

The last time I drove through the Point was this morning, and I drove down Peabody Street headed towards the Congress Street bridge.  I want to change the electric transfer station on the north side of Peabody Street!  It looks like a horror movie with the rusted gate, barbed wire and gross looking, empty lot next to the machinery.  Can't they do better than that?!  The City and the neighborhood should demand that National Grid take care of their site since it is the middle of a residential neighborhood right on the edge of the Harborwalk.  Enough is enough with that site.

I think the shop should think about re-branding themselves and marketing their shop both within the neighborhood and in downtown Salem.  There are a lot of new people who have moved to both downtown and the Point in the past few years who probably do not have a relationship with a particular electrician - having someone local, convenient and good is key to repeat business.  Maybe also sprucing up the place with a new paint job, new signage, etc. would help make it seem fresh to locals.
[[[42.51564993962491, -70.89096146202087]]]\nI like the pupusa's at the Palmer Street market!

I think people can get most basic household goods and foods at the local markets, although they are probably more expensive than some of the larger markets outside of the neighborhood.  There is also access to laundromats and cleaners.  People have to leave the neighborhood to buy larger quantities of household goods (Target, WalMart, etc.), and people have to leave the neighborhood  for clothing.  There also are not a lot of restaurant options in the Point.  It blows my mind that there are not several great dominican restaurants in the neighborhood!

I think trash is a big problem in the Point.  The problem is so multi-faceted:  city pickups being once per week is not enough in this dense of a neighborhood; too many people litter; high-traffic businesses like Wendy's and the bodegas sell a lot of things that lend themself to litter (nips, candy bars, etc.); and landlords do not provide decent trash barrels in so many instances.  There is no magic bullet, but several things need to happen to address the trash problem in the Point.

OK\nI think the City does a lot more in the Point than is generally known.  Primarily through CDBG, they fund a lot of the programs and services people know and love.Also, it's great that the city invested so much time, energy and money into the renovation of things like the Peabody St. Park and the intersection of Ward, Peabody & Congress Street.But I think a much better job could be done in keeping up the streets, sidewalks, signage and in taking care of the trash problem.  I think the City and the neighborhood need to start looking at new ideas for some of these things - the same old thing is not working.
replies: Well said!  I can recall worrying about drug activity in the Point twenty years ago, and I feel much the same way now. Whatever is being done, in this regard, is NOT working.

response: I work in the Point, so I'm here nearly every day.  I love that you can walk everywhere - from downtown Salem and the farmer's market in the summer, to the Harborwalk, to the marina and within the Point to all the parks.  I love to eat lunch in Peabody Street Park or Palmer Cove when it's nice out in the spring/summer.  I also love all of the bodegas.  I get my plantains there all the time, and I get dominican snacks in the afternoon when I would not know where else to get them.  There are always homemade foods in the bodegas, some of which I don't even know what they are!
replies: Yes! Being able to walk to so many great locations was my favorite part of living in the Point, and the thing I miss most now that I've moved away.

response: [[[42.518813118590025, -70.89174466705322]]]\nI love the Peabody Street Park and almost always take visitors there when I have the chance. I think a bit of news in the last year was the tearing down of St. Joseph's Church.  This is good and bad for the neighborhood.  On the one hand, it was for a long time a place of community and gathering for the neighborhood.  But on the other hand, it has been vacant for about 10 years, and since it's been vacant has become a problem area for the neighborhood.  The tear-down represents progress and hope for a revitalized site with nice buildings, people living there and caring about their neighborhood, and hopefully some good retail that the neighborhood can use.

two times I took particular pride in the Point:1) last 'Youth Get to the Point' day - there were well over 100 young people working on community service projects throughout the neighborhood, and the day culminated with a part in the Peabody Street Park for the unveiling of a new mural which young people designed and created.  Such a sense of pride and happiness in the area.2) when Lucy Corchado was elected to the City Council - she is and has always been a great leader in the community, and her activism and representation has been symbolic in the city.

response: Grocery shopping, Cultural, social, entertainment\nthe Point has some great bodegas!  you can get fruits, vegetables and all sorts of stuff that you would never find at a larger grocery store.  best plantains around!

It would be a shame to visit Salem and not see the Point.  The idea that the Point is dangerous is really just an old wives' tale - the people in the Point are welcoming and friendly.  There is a lot of great food to be had in the Point, whether from the little bodegas with their homemade Dominican treats or at Harbor Sweets.  The parks are great - everyone uses Palmer Cove at some point growing up, Mary Jane Lee needs to be renovated, but it's a great neighborhood park, and the Peabody Street Park is gorgeous and right on the new Harborwalk.  In the summer, there is live music there all the time.  And many people who visit Salem are interested in history and architecture, and the Point is just such a treasure with such a unique history of culture, new Americans and diversity.
replies: Such a great description!

response: [[[42.51841772997585, -70.8930750427246]]]\nI have taken people on tours of the Point several times, and I almost always start on Peabody Street.  I think it's one of the most beautiful, particularly with the Peabody Street Park, the Harborwalk and the two murals on it.  The architecture on Peabody is some of the best in the city.  Then, I go up Congress Street, weave into Harbor Street, go down Prince Street to Mary Jane Lee Park, another key part of the neighborhood.  Then I walk up Palmer Street, back up Congress over to Palmer Cove Park and by the marina and Harbor Sweets, and then back up Palmer all the way to Lafayette.
Beautiful architecture!  Best kept secret in Salem.

OK\nIt's hard for me to judge; there are lots of things that clearly need improvement --- I have to maneuver around massive potholes every day, but there are improvements being made --  the expansion to the youth center (?) at Palmer's Cove.Also, I'd love to see more businesses with staying power that appeal to wider demographics.  It seems small shops frequently open and then quickly close in the Point.  Some -- like the glittery dress shop and the pipe shop -- appeal to a very limited clientele therefore not attracting a variety of customers.

I love how close the point is to downtown.  When the weather is nice, I will walk to get coffee or a snack.  I also like to go on walks and jogs, so I will often run along the water down to the Willows.

Charles is more right than wrong. As sadly, the negatives of The Point outweigh the positives.  My biggest qualm with the point is the high number of sex offenders in the neighborhood.  Since I work at a SACS, I regularly get emails reminding me to keep our doors locked.with names and pictures of the neighborhood sex offenders attached.  The neighborhood is also riddled with homeless people, people who live in halfway houses, drug dealers and addicts, as well as prostitutes.  Sadly, I would not send a tourist to the point.  Charles is "wrong" as The Point has potential.  There is culture, diversity, and a sense of community in the point.  There are some gorgeous murals and a sea view!  Some of the architecture is quite pretty especially some of the brick 1920s buildings (by Harborsweets).  Though Shetland has some pretty buildings, it is mostly a vast, white eyesore surrounded by concrete.

[[[42.51715246959782, -70.8901567993164]]]\nThere is a mural here, or right near this spot.  I think it captures the potential I see in the point: bright colors, smiling faces, vibrancy, a sense of joy.

LifeBridge has temporary solutions for food and shelter, as does the YMCA. Overall, I would advise to consult with a local government official for adequate housing placement from a non-profit.

The beauty of the Point is less in it's current physical state, and more about the spirit it could tap into. In this photo, we see the mayor with young community members. That's a symbolic image that should carry over.

[[[42.518125140790886, -70.88906245803832]]]\nShetland Park is an area where PUD interests are fully realized, but with underutilized incentives for the neighborhood and small businesses. I believe that we could create opportunities for community members, youth and small business in spaces that are otherwise vacant and create interest in an entrepreneurial spirit, or artistic vision for youth to feel like they can safely work in and toward a brighter future.

Former resident, and now City Councillor William Legault shares his memories in this article (http://salem.patch.com/articles/a-point-kid-remembers-the-past-and-considers-the-present) about growing up in the area. It's clear that the Point has long suffered from PR blues and if I was trying to rethink a positive spin for the zone, I would craft a headline like:"The Point Remains Focal Point for Salem's True Grit"This title suggests that the Point must remain central to Salem's redevelopment plans and determination is needed to get the entire community involved.

I do not live in the Point, but I would imagine many residents go to the various connivence stores/gas stations in the area to get basic needs fulfilled. Otherwise, Walgreens and CVS are within walking distance, too. A more robust shopping experience could be had at the mall, but for full scale shopping, a bus trip to the Market Basket/Target/Shaw's at Highland Ave would likely be my charted path.

[[[42.5167807944939, -70.89145498847961]]]\nA former friend of mine lived on Salem Street here - between the needles, house robberies, loud music and crowded streets, this area is the epitome of what needs to change for the Point. People should feel welcome and safe, not scared and confused.
I agree with the consensus map.

More visual stimulus. From branded street signs with a cohesive voice/vision, to more plants and flowers, to more art and murals - I want to see a concerted effort to clean up the area, showcase pride of community, and create dedicated days of beatification in a street by street challenge.

http://www.flickr.com/photos/44747327@N04/8071389184/in/set-72157631675997424Showcasing the colors, diversity and uniqueness of the Point within this mural is a beautiful way of symbolically and physically trying to brighten up the area. More art initiatives should be considered to get the community to actively maintain a cultured space.

Consumer products (e.g., clothes), Cultural, social, entertainment\nSome of the newer shops in the area have provided a unique atmosphere, like the Witch Doctor. However, I'm hesitant to label said establishment as a top attraction; more consumer friendly options would help this area tremendously.

Check in with someone from Community Teamwork, Inc. to see if someone from the housing and consumer resources center can help you out. Unfortunately, CTI is in Lowell, so it's hard to get there from here and Metropolitan Boston Housing Partnership only serves greater Boston, not Salem.DTA might be able to help temporarily, but is not likely due to constant budget cuts and a priority for families. There are some other shelters out there too, but beds fill up fast, I'm told.

Commercial business rehabilitation,  Job creation,  Job training and placement\nI hear a lot about how more [blue collar] jobs are needed. If we can't create those jobs, we need to be training the workforce on how to move into new jobs.

More affordable rental housing, Energy efficiency improvements, More affordable home ownership, Assistance to rehabilitate homes\nMaking improvements to the current housing stock is crucial to neighborhood revitalization. Making sure that immigrant families and the "working poor" have access to housing they can afford as they work toward achieving the American Dream is also necessary and should be a priority.
I would like to see something new that benefits the community on the vacant lot at Prince Street and Palmer Street.

Though I generally feel safe in the Point neighborhood, it is intimidating to encounter a group of men loitering in the street--in any neighborhood. It is especially disturbing when the street is not well lit and the men make cat calls and harassing comments. As a woman, I tend to avoid that situation as much as possible and will cross the street to avoid groups of people or will drive directly to where I need to be so that I feel safer.

[[[42.5178871, -70.8893569]], [[42.5178871, -70.8893569]]]\nI noticed over the summer when North Shore CDC's youth jobs program had barrels out that the intersection of Harbor and Congress Streets improved the most in the shortest amount of time. There is a lot of pedestrian traffic there from the businesses in Shetland park, youth walking home from school, etc. Having barrels there (and other places in the neighborhood) would definitely make a difference!
Having access to resources to develop a long term business and marketing plan would be helpful for Timothy and his brother. Is there any place in Salem that offers these services?
The health center is a great community resource. I think that most Point residents have to leave the neighborhood for jobs, which can be challenging to coordinate with access to transportation.

[[[42.51807, -70.88946699999997]]]\nDeli House has great food, very reasonable prices, and an owner who cares about the community. I only wish there was seating so that one could eat there instead of having to take everything to go.

response: Traffic, both pedestrian and vehicle, is very loud here. Horns honk all the time, fire engines are extremely loud and I can clearly hear a lot of conversations taking place on the sidewalk.

The best part about working in the Point is being able to walk everywhere and having so many quality restaurant options for lunch. The Prime gas station on Palmer Street also has the cheapest gas in the city and is a quick stop on the way to the office.

Market Basket on Highland Avenue has the best prices and selection on food. It's at least a 5-10 minute drive and is always packed with people. It's close to Target, which has a pharmacy and personal items, but I'd probably pick up my prescription and grab some toothpaste at the Walgreens on Derby Street that's within walking distance.

I'd want to make sure to plan games that are simple enough for people of any age to play and for which they could team up. I'm sure there must be plenty of new games, but the first ones to pop into my head are classics like three-legged races, egg or water balloon tosses, egg-and-spoon or other relay-style races. How about a dunk tank featuring local dignitaries -- politicians, neighborhood leaders, City employees (except for me) as potential "dunkees?"  A free raffle with multiple prizes appropriate for guests of various ages. A scavenger hunt. Oh, and of course, food. Lots of food. After all, who doesn't like to eat?!?  :D
