[[[42.5178871, -70.8893569]]]\nI'd shut down Congress Street between Palmer and Leavitt for the block party. Congress Street is wider than most (all?) streets in The Point and there would be easy access to Palmer Cove Park. I'd want to have a basketball tournament and a softball game with teams representing particular streets, or combinations of streets. Maybe a barbecue contest. Or how about getting into the Guinness Book of World's Records with the world's largest-ever pastelito? Could we get a Salem Fire Department ladder truck for kids to climb on and check out?  Ahhh, warm weather can't come soon enough!

Don't Know (I don't live in the Point)\nI've driven past Mary Jane Lee Park a few times, but never paid enough attention to make an informed evaluation of it. I know the infield at the Palmer Cove baseball field was recently renovated, but I don't know much about other details there. I can recall having walked the path beyond the outfield fence, at the edge of the water, and it offered some nice views. Yes, I DO work for the Salem Parks, Recreation & Community Services Department, but I rarely venture beyond the walls of the Senior Center for my job, which is primarily with senior citizens.

If Linda is limited to The Point, the best place for her to take her children would -- rather obviously -- be Mary Jane Lee Park.  I met Mariah, another "what's the Point?" player, at last week's MeetUp in the North Shore CDC conference room and she mentioned that the playground there isn't fully fenced in. Linda would have to keep a close eye on her children, especially at the ages of 3 and 4. Kids that age can be very quick and unpredictable so they could make it into the street in a heartbeat if their mom wasn't paying close attention. The streets adjacent to the park are not heavily traveled, but Linda wouldn't want to sit and read a magazine while her children cruised the playground. An alternative spot would be the Palmer Cove park. There's enough open space there for Linda to engage her children in games but, again, she'd want to be heads-up about how much range she allowed them. Then again, if Linda has her M.Ed., I'm sure she's well aware of how to manage a couple energetic preschoolers anyway!

[[[42.51900726800119, -70.89537884232789]]]\nMetered parking spots, eh? Hmmm ... Since my geographic boundaries of The Point in previous challenges seem to have been too narrow, I'd pick the metered parking lots at the corner of Washington and Dodge streets. There are some trees there, with lots of space and it would be a very prominent location. I'd want to host a multi-cultural fair featuring artwork, clothing, food and music.

Safe, Quiet, Drug/alcohol-free/non-smoking, Sporting equipment/facilities available, Outdoors\nI love to be outdoors and the older I become the more peaceful I like my surroundings to be. I'm not painfully fussy, but I'm increasing inclined to invest time and energy in getting to places to be where I really want to spend my leisure time.

If I lived in The Point, I wouldn't have to go far during the warm-weather months because I'd want to spend as much time as possible doing something with a baseball on the field at Palmer Cove. If I was car-less, I'd use my bicycle to ride to other parks or fields, or places where I could enjoy nature, like Forest River Park (swimming pool), Winter Island Park (beach), The Willows, Olde Salem Greens golf course, etc.  In the winter months, since I can't think of many sledding hills near The Point, I might try to get into a pair of cross-country skis and hope there's enough snow to use them in the Palmer Cove park. I'd want to see at least a mid-sized strip mall in close proximity to my home and, if I'm allowed to dream a little, I'd like to see the Boys & Girls Club of Greater Salem relocate to a new facility in or near The Point. I wonder if there's enough space somewhere in the Shetland Property to house the Club and some good gym space.
replies: A Boys if Girls Club in the Point is a brilliant idea!

response: For starters, I'd want to know what Freddy did to warrant getting booted off the team. That might influence my choice of recommendations for him, but without knowing that my initial response would be to suggest he check in at the Boys & Girls Club of Greater Salem.  It's within easy walking distance and there's an indoor gym where he could hone his hoops skills your-round.  I might also suggest he check out the programs and activities offered by the City of Salem's Recreation Department. He might consider playing in a City-sponsored youth basketball league with his peers, or even look into volunteering for a youth league for elementary-age kids. Beyond those options, I'd encourage him to think about volunteering at a nearby non-profit or, depending on his age, look for some part-time work within walking or bicycling distance after school and/or on weekends. If I knew Freddy well enough, I'd also want to make sure I had an eye-to-eye and heart-to-heart conversation with him about being smart about who he hangs with.

Four or more times a week\nI'm definitely an outside person in the summer. Like most other people, I tend to hunker down and stay inside all winter. In warm weather, you won't find me inside much at all. I ride my bicycle from my home in Beverly to my job in Salem every day, year-round. I'll play anything that involves a ball of any size or shape and love to hike around woods and lakes.

If I'm free on a Friday night, I wouldn't go anywhere in The Point, but I might get close.  If I had something to celebrate or there was some special occasion, I'd consider going to the Grapevine restaurant on Congress Street, or maybe try the Red Lulu Cocina on Lafayette Street. I live in Beverly and on a free weekend evening, I tend to travel in the direction of Newburyport or Gloucester, not typically south or west.
replies: Agreed, I've heard good things about both places but haven't tried either, yet. Though Grapevine currently has a deal on LivingSocial.  I'm tempted to buy it:http://www.livingsocial.com/deals/599318-60-to-spend-on-mediterranean-fare

response: [[[42.51372242082454, -70.88854077832644]], [[42.525910449834385, -70.87036176840206]]]\nI might not be very helpful with this challenge because I work in Salem but I live in Beverly. (Don't hold that against me!) In other words, Salem is not usually a place I go to "hang out," but Winter Island Park is a great place to be. In summer or winter, it always offer excellent views, featuring a lighthouse, a beach, boats, and other seaside vistas.  If I had to pick a place in The Point, I'd probably go to the park at Palmer Cove. If nothing else, I'd enjoy the view of the water, but in the warm-weather months I'd also like to play some hoops or find a friend to have a catch or hit some out at the baseball field. If the weather was bad and I'd be stuck inside, I'd go to the Salem Public Library or, if I was in The Point, I guess I'd probably plant myself at Wendy's for a while.and hope a friend would show up.

Job creation,  Job training and placement\nThis is a tough question, but I'd lean toward funding programs that facilitate employment for residents in The Point. I'm very fortunate to have been able to find work during my 40 adult years, but I cal still recall, painfully, a 10-week period during which I was unemployed. I'd been laid off as an office supply delivery man for Sawtell Office Supply on Washington Street in Salem. Remember it? It was where Caffe Graziani is now. Anyway, I was married and had two young children and remember the frustration of looking for work unsuccessfully. One late afternoon, after yet another fruitless train ride into Boston for my job search, I sat on a bench at the Beverly station, hung my face in my hands and began to sob. I'd never felt so worthless and helpless in my life, and it grieves me to this day to think about anyone who wants to work -- needs to work -- but can't find a job. (Don't even get me started on the NAFTA and job outsourcing.)

More affordable rental housing\nI've been a devoted renter all my adult life, and have never considered home ownership any part of my American dream. Ever.  Then again, I've never wanted to rent an apartment in a large complex. I've always been able to find apartments in former single-family houses, none of which were ever split up into more than four units. I always want to know who the neighbors in my building will be, and to know I can contact my landlord directly.  So, from my perspective, I'd like to see more affordable rental housing in The Point, along with the elimination of the large, ominous-looking apartment buildings that are there now. I'm not sure what kind of housing went up at the corner of Palmer and Congress streets several years ago, but I'd be much more inclined to move into an attractive building like that than into the older several-story buildings, such as those along Peabody Street.

If I was Timothy, my response would depend on several factors, like how well I knew the neighbor, why he/she was evicted, and if he/she had family members living anywhere in the area. When I was younger and thought I could save the world, I'd probably have welcomed the neighbor to stay with me for a while. Now, knowing how many social service agencies -- including shelters for homeless people -- might be able to address my neighbor's issues, I'd refer him/her to any or all of them. I'd make a list, include phone numbers and offer rides to help facilitate contact with agencies that are accustomed to dealing with such problems and would be able to give my neighbor far more information and viable options that I could.

[[[42.5146851381747, -70.8901567993164]], [[42.5186362, -70.8912029]], [[42.5186362, -70.8912029]]]\nI'm not very familiar with trash trouble spots in The Point, but I'd assume Peabody Street near Wendy's restaurant would be a fairly common dumping ground for patrons discarding wrappers and containers. I think there are litter problems at all fast-food places, especially ones with drive-through service. Patrons pull in, grab a bag of food at a window, then drive off, unwrap their grub and chuck the papers out the window. That might be especially true in the area behind the restaurant, including the canal, where there don't seem to be many people watching.

I'll admit it. In the fall of 2009, a Dominican friend of mine and I were going door-to-door in The Point, looking for senior citizens to survey them about how the Salem Council on Aging could be of service. Our goal was to knock on every last door of every single residence, but we didn't anticipate how forbidding the large brick apartment buildings could be. We left some of our flyers at the main entrances, where we could, but decided not to venture inside to go through the hallways knocking on doors. We felt intimidated about the thought of going deep inside one of those apartment buildings and out of sight. In reflecting on my own feelings, I wasn't afraid of being verbally or physically threatened inside the building, but I was nervous about knocking on doors of people I assumed -- maybe incorrectly -- wouldn't have appreciated their day being interrupted. I pictured us simply being sneered at or having doors shut in our faces. I guess it boiled down to this: The inhospitable feeling we had from the outside of the building made us feel there would be inhospitable people living inside.

I can remember my last drive through The Point exactly. Every Thursday evening I drive a Salem Council on Aging van to take someone home. I take a left from Lafayette Street at Wendy's restaurant onto Peabody Street. I drop my passenger off at an apartment building on Peabody Street, across from what I think is an electrical facility. Then I take a right onto Congress and another right onto Harbor, crossing Lafayette at the new set of traffic lights. The COA van isn't very wide, but I always feel cramped on Peabody and Harbor streets. With cars parked on both sides, I proceed very slowly, afraid someone will carelessly fling open a car door in my path. If I could change anything, it would be to widen the roads or restrict parking to only one side. I know the latter suggestion would create a severe parking issue for residents in the large apartment buildings, but -- get this -- I'd create 24-hour valet parking jobs at each of those buildings. Imagine!  It would be just like in New York City where there are huge apartment buildings and hundreds of residents, but not nearly enough space to park all their cars. You pull your car up right out front, some guy in a red jacket holds your door open for you and then drives your car to a designated garage. Pretty fancy, right? OK, so maybe that's not realistic, but it's what I'd change if I could. And while I'm on Peabody Street, maybe I should also mention I'd tear down the electrical facility and fill that lot with a new Boys & Girls Club or a supermarket. Can't we relocate that electric facility somewhere else? It makes the neighborhood beyond look like a state correctional facility!

I'm no businessman, but if Timothy is friendly, well liked and good at communicating I think it would be good to learn how to use a computer to effectively market himself and his business. There are so many ways to network online and many of them are free services. Maybe Timothy could also volunteer to do some small electrical work for non-profit organizations or agencies. That would be another way in which he could network, exhibit his skills and, hopefully, get some people in the non-profit to tell their friends and family members about him and his abilities.

[[[42.518649, -70.89309200000002]]]\nBased on my boundaries of The Point neighborhood, the Grapevine is just a few doors too far along Congress Street to qualify, although it would be my favorite restaurant. In truth, I can't really afford to eat there very often. I've gone there when they participate in the annual Super Hunger Brunch fundraiser for the Greater Boston Food Bank, and on one or two other very special occasions, but it would be a budget-buster on any kind of regular basis. I've never been to the Brisas del Caribe or the place on the east side of Congress Street that seems to change hands on a monthly basis. I've eaten at the Tipico on Congress Street a few times, but my American palate would most often point me in the direction of Wendy's. I'll have a crispy chicken caesar wrap and a wild berry lemonade, please. Truth is, though, I wish I knew a Dominican in The Point who makes great bacalao. If there's ever a Best Bacalao contest in The Point, I'd be happy to volunteer to be a judge!

Based on my earlier geographic definition of The Point, while never having lived there, I'd say few restaurants are available, as well as a handful of small convenience markets, lottery outlets, a health clinic, a car repair shop, a place for information and support on immigration, a chocolate shop, a church, a child care center, some independent handymen and a gas station. I suspect there are lots of businesses tucked away in Shetland Park, although I have no idea exactly what and it seems like such a cold and unwelcoming complex of buildings I wouldn't even be inclined to explore it. I think there's a juvenile court there, maybe, as well as some kind of yacht club nearby, but I'd sincerely hope I'd never have a reason to go to either of them!  If I lived in The Point, I think I'd have to leave it to find a pharmacy, a gift shop, a clothing store, household goods, a large selection of groceries, a florist and, obviously, a other goods and services too numerous to mention.

I don't live in The Point, but I've driven vans for the Salem Council on Aging and have picked up and dropped off passengers in that neighborhood many times. I've also visited The Point for various reasons. From that perspective, my impression of The Point is that there are a lot of people and buildings crammed into a not a lot of space. I know the entire City is dense, accommodating more than 40,000 people in about eight square miles of space. That's an average of about 5,000 people per square mile, but breathing room in The Point is much harder to come by. In that neighborhood, the average is more than 12,000 people per square mile. Adding to the sense of compression is a vague feeling I get as a driver. With so many one-way streets, I get the feeling that if I can find my way into The Point, I'm going to stuggle to find my way out. Overall, The Point feels like a thicket of wild rose bushes to me -- a neighborhood that has sometimes yields attractive blooms, but one in which people get become snagged, disoriented and trapped.  I'd like to change The Point by creating more breathing room for residents and expanding road access in and through the neighborhood.

OK\nI'm a City employee, but I've long felt that most people in Salem outside The Point, including the municipal government, treats residents of the neighborhood and the area with benign neglect. Fortunately, I think Mayor Driscoll has been more invested in reaching out to The Point than several Mayors before her. It's long seemed to me, however, that The Point is viewed as a world unto itself, a place outsiders simply don't pay much attention to or in which not a lot of time and energy is focused. People don't do things that are clearly detrimental to The Point, but they don't do much to do anything of benefit to it either. The Point is just, well ... there. This is an extension of my feeling that The Point is isolated, the word I used as my answer to the very first challenge in Mission 1. To help minimize that isolation, I'd want to make Congress Street a main thoroughfare connected to Lafayette Street (at the Leavitt Street end), instead of what amounts to little more than a dead end.

I do not live in The Point, but I think an advantage would be living in a neighborhood that's close to downtown Salem, within easy walking or bicycling distance of shops, markets, banks, cafes, restaurants, entertainment venues, government offices, a post office, a health clinic, social service agencies, public transportation, historic sites, a baseball field ... and, of course, a place that sells handmade chocolates. (Just wondering: How many Sweet Sloops would be considered too much of a good thing?) Anyway, living in such close proximity to the downtown, with so many goods and services available, would minimize my need to use a car. I'm not a big fan of cars. Walking or bicycling is better for my health, my wallet and the environment.

[[[42.513680779859385, -70.88810759162902]]]\nI'd end a tour of The Point at Palmer Cove, directing the attention of visitors out over the water. A water view has a way of giving people a sense of openness, a feeling like there is always the possibility for something new and exciting on the horizon. It fosters a feeling of expansiveness and potential. In a way, I feel that the water view from Palmer Cove Park is the biggest and best window for people in The Point. It seems to be the one spot, on the edge of the neighborhood that isn't somehow walled off by manmade barriers. It offers an opening to the world not enjoyed at any other place in the neighborhood.

MAKING A PITCHMinor league baseball team tosses out a proposal to play at Palmer CoveAn independent baseball league official recently inquired about the possibility of having Salem host a team at the Palmer Cove field.  The official's proposal to the City would include upgrades to the field, along with new permanent seating, a concession stand and bathrooms, the bill for which would be footed by the baseball league. A lack of parking potential could pose a problem, but the league's representative likes the location and feels the presence of a minor league team could bring new vitality to The Point, along with a stronger sense of neighborhood identity. "The community at large would benefit, too," said the league rep. "A minor league baseball team would give residents a rallying point, and I think it would be a hit with nearby residents. It certainly wouldn't hurt the local economy, either." It was not overlooked, by league officials, that the strong presence of Dominican residents in the nearby Point area could play a role in the success of a team based at Palmer Cove. "Beisbol" is, far and away, the most popular sport in the Dominican Republic.

I don't live in The Point.  If I owned a car, I think I'd do to a shopping plaza on Highland Avenue to find everything I'd need in one place. I think I can also take an MBTA bus there from a few spots on Lafayette St., but that seems like a pretty big ordeal, especially if I need to pick up more than two bags of items. Without a car (or a friend to ask for a ride) I'd probably walk in the direction of downtown Salem and head for the Walgreen's on New Derby St., and either the Los Amigos market on Lafayette or Steve's Market on Margin St., depending on how bare my cupboard happened to be. If I only needed a few things, I'd stroll to one of the very small markets that dot The Point neighborhood.  If I was disabled, or 60 years of age or older, I'd contact the Council on Aging so sign up for a free weekly van ride to Market Basket or WalMart (both on Highland Ave.), or to Crosby's Marketplace (Canal St.).

[[[42.51883684182776, -70.89133160686492]]]\nHonestly, I have no idea what the property right next to the Peabody Street Park is, but if I was giving a visitor a tour of The Point, I'd desperately try to distract him/her from looking at it.  The old brick building is enough of an eyesore, but then there's a metallic thorn bush of pipes and wires and rods that's even more painful to look at. If I was a film director making a new version of "Frankenstein," I'd have the creature hooked up to that mess when I flipped the switch to bring it to life.  I know, I know ... it's probably some electric transfer station that supplies power to half the City of Salem, or something like that. If that's the case, I'd rather revert to gaslight or candlelight than have to look it every time I approached The Point. Are there any two side-by-side spots in the City that are any less congruous than the friendly little park next to the giant bug-zapper that could take down a pterodactyl?

When I think of The Point as a neighborhood of residents, I think of the streets in the darker green area. When I think of it geographically, I include everything north to the canal at the Salem Harbor Walk and east to Salem Harbor.  I never think of The Point beyond Leavitt Street to the south or Lafayette St. to the west.

Great question! For starters, I think people are generally more inclined to feel and express pride in places when they're geographically larger. In other words, as I think about this question for myself. I've never sensed much pride in my street, but there's a little more potential for pride when I consider my neighborhood, and even more when I think about my hometown (Morristown, N.J.) I have even more pride, and express it more readily, for my home state. Maybe it has to do with feeling more pride when we feel part of a bigger group of people. I've become increasingly proud of the U.S. and its place in the global community, lately, as I meet and communicate online with people in other parts of the world. Our country has its flaws, of course, but many people worldwide long to come to America because the know we enjoy freedoms not available to them. Everything is relative, right? OK, now back to the question! I took a little pride in my neighborhood because there was a national historic site -- Washington's headquarters at the Ford Mansion -- at the end of my street. I thought that was pretty cool, although I took it for granted and never visited it. I was more proud of my hometown for the role it played in the American Revolution, when its high school sports teams succeeded and when I learned about famous people who lived there -- like two presidents' wives, cartoonist Thomas Nast, Detroit Tigers pitchers Rick Porcello and the Craig of criagslist, Craig Newmark. I think I'd have been more proud of my neighborhood if there had been more obvious interactions between neighbors. The kids played together frequently at a local playground, but we never had block parties or came together to rally in support of any worthwhile causes. Neighbors stayed pretty much to themselves when I was growing up in Morristown in the '60s, maybe because it was a very controversial and divisive decade.
replies: For me, pride comes from living history. Just the past, or just the present alone isn't quite enough for me. I'm from Ann Arbor, MI, and the history of 60s counterculture and activism shows up in everything from the kinds of performance spaces, stores, and cafes to course offerings at various schools in the university to the student cooperatives and, well, the general culture of the city.

response: The baseball diamond at Palmer Cove!  Since my favorite sport, by far, is baseball, I see beauty in every baseball diamond, no matter how humble or grand.  I have a very romantic perspective on baseball because most of the dreams I dreamed as a child were staged on a baseball field. Video clips of spectacular diving catches and walk-off home runs were played in my head every day, even though I rarely did either in reality. A baseball field, to me, is a place where hope and dreams are encouraged to play. Baseball is a sport that requires teamwork -- people cooperating and working together toward a common goal. It is also the only team sport in which time is not a factor. Time will never diminish or limit your team's chances of succeeding. There's no clock to watch. I agree with French educator Jacques Barzun: "Whoever wants to know the heart and mind of America had better learn baseball, the rules and realities of the game •À_ and do it by watching first some high school or small-town teams."

Cultural, social, entertainment\nMy specific answer would be history, which is the reason The Point is such a culturally and socially unique neighborhood, not only in Salem, but on the North Shore of Massachusetts.  The history of The Point is not readily apparent for those simply looking for "attractions," but it is available to those who are looking for it. While immigrant populations past and present may struggle with language barriers, I think it's important for visitors and residents alike to listen to those who are fluent in the language of "history!"  History, when known and understood, can create a strong sense of place among people, especially for those who have left their homelands behind.

If Charles is interested ONLY in supernatural phenomena and the Halloweeny side of Salem, he's probably right that The Point is not worth visiting.  If he is at all interested in the City's maritime history, the history of the mills, the Great Salem Fire of 1914 that destroyed the Pequot Mill, immigration and labor unions, he should consider The Point a must-see!  I suspect the ghost tour guide's interests don't include such topics.
replies: There really are no ghost tours there, only dowtown.

response: [[[42.515988, -70.890217]]]\nI'd start at Mary Jane Lee Park because it's a green space and playground in the heart of the neighborhood. It is open to everyone and the purpose is to offer a play to have fun, play and relax. I would walk along a couple of the narrow streets, pointing out the residences. The I would head to Shetland Park to share the history of the mills and how French-Canadian and Polish immigrants moved into The Point to work in them. So, my tour would start at a place of play, rest and relaxation and end with a place where immigrants worked very hard, side-by-side, in the hope of improving their lives. (Mill photo from masshumanities.org, The Massachusetts Foundation for the Humanities.)
replies: I didn't know Shetland Park was a mill. Interesting history.\\ I'd go on this tour!

response: My postcard would show people who are interested in The Point in a heartfelt way and want to make it a more excellent neighborhood, even though they do not live there. This picture, taken on Congress Street, shows Mayor Driscoll, two student-interns from Salem State University and a Dominican senior citizen, all of whom have helped "personas de tercera edad en el Punto."  Ideally, I would like my postcard to show people who actually live in The Point and are similarly invested in their own neighborhood. :)
Isolated.
replies: Yeah, its unfair because some people dont consider it a part of Salem.

response: Nothing.

If i Were To Make A Post Card About The Point I'd Say That The Point Is A Very Amazing/Great Place. And That It Is A Great Community. Another Thing I'd Put Is That I Also Love The Point Because Everyone Is Familiar With Each Other.
I Love The Point. I Have Been Living Here Since I Was Born & Im 12 Years Old. This is a great place to be.
